ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Central Deafness (Cortical Deafness)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Dissociation between intact peripheral function (normal reflexes, present ABR) and profound central deficit (absent MLR/Late potentials, inability to recognize speech).

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity, though results were extremely variable and unreliable.
To assess speech detection and recognition capabilities.
To evaluate brainstem/peripheral auditory pathway integrity.
To assess neural integrity of the auditory nerve and brainstem.
To assess thalamocortical auditory pathway function.
To visualize the location and extent of cerebrovascular lesions.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals a classic profile of central deafness. Peripheral auditory mechanisms are intact as evidenced by normal acoustic reflexes and preserved ABR Wave V. However, central auditory processing is profoundly disrupted, indicated by the absence of MLR and Late Potentials, and the inability to recognize speech or reliably respond to tones. The patient is functionally deaf despite peripheral integrity.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Extreme variability in thresholds; estimates ranged from mild-moderate flat loss to profound loss/no response; reliability consistently poor.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Speech detection thresholds (SDT) approx 10-15 dB HL (Right) and 30 dB HL (Left); speech recognition scores could never be established (patient could not understand words).

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Wave V present bilaterally down to ~50 dB nHL; slightly low amplitude; normal I-V interwave intervals.

tests.name: Middle Latency Response (MLR)
tests.result_summary: Absent; no repeatable responses observed for either ear.

tests.name: Late Auditory Evoked Potentials
tests.result_summary: Absent; failed to demonstrate repeatable responses.

tests.name: Radiologic Evaluation (CT)
tests.result_summary: Bilateral lesions. Right: Extensive involvement of temporal (including Heschl's), parietal, and frontal lobes. Left: Patchy low density in temporal/parietal areas; Left Heschl's gyrus interpreted as intact.

proposed_items: Reliance on non-auditory communication strategies such as writing, signing, and visual cues
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of Central Deafness: the ears are working, but the brain cannot process sound into meaning
Discuss that inconsistency in hearing tests is a symptom of the brain injury, not malingering
Advise that recovery has been minimal and is likely limited by age and extent of lesions
Explain that the tinnitus is likely central in origin

escalation.destination: Neurology and Audiology for long-term monitoring
escalation.rationale_short: Patient is stable post-stroke; long-term follow-up required to monitor for any potential recovery.

follow_up_plan.objective: To monitor auditory behavior and potential recovery of function.

expected_outcome: Transient improvement in auditory behavior observed over 8 years of follow-up.
Extreme variability in pure tone thresholds persisted, ranging from mild-moderate to profound loss.
Speech recognition scores could never be established as the patient could not understand words.
Patient maintained reliance on writing as the main means of communication.
